This scene showcased her warmth and ability to connect with others, making Rudolph feel a sense of belonging and camaraderie.

However, as the story progressed, it became clear that Mrs. Forrester's relationship with Rudolph was more complex and multifaceted. When Rudolph dismounted from his horse, pale but with a calmness he was proud of, Mrs. Forrester turned to him with a look of understanding and concern. This moment suggested a deeper connection between them, one that went beyond mere friendship or social acquaintance.

Their conversation in the dark well of the pagoda stairway further deepened their connection. Mrs. Forrester's words, "The best? Don't you think you have a better?" and her subsequent laughter, revealed a playful and flirtatious side to her personality. Rudolph's response, his willingness to defend her and his passion, indicated a strong emotional investment in their relationship.

The scene where Mrs. Forrester led Rudolph to the tiled gateway and rested her hand on his forearm marked a turning point in their relationship. This intimate gesture, combined with her words of apology and regret, suggested a level of emotional vulnerability and trust between them. Rudolph's reaction, his awareness of the nearness and pallor of her face, the darkness of her eyes shining up at him, indicated a strong physical and emotional attraction.

However, the arrival of the ship's doctor and his jocular comment about Mrs. Forrester's title, "Mrs. Forrester," revealed a darker truth about their relationship. Rudolph's demand for an explanation, his trembling voice, and his subsequent shame and revulsion, suggested that he had been deceived about Mrs. Forrester's identity and status.

In this context, the relationship between Rudolph and Mrs. Forrester developed from a warm and playful connection to a complex and emotionally charged one, marked by deception, vulnerability, and ultimately, shame and revulsion.

At the foot of this aged fantasy in stone, people were laughing. The three riders broke cover in time to see Mrs. Forrester, flushed and radiant, end some narrative with a droll pantomime. She stood laughing, the life and centre of a delighted group. "And Gilbert Forrester," she cried, turning archly on her husband, "said that wasn't funny!" Gilly tugged his gray moustache, in high good-nature. Chantel, Nesbit, and Kempner laughed uproariously, the padre and the dark-eyed Miss Drake quietly, Heywood more quietly, while even stout, uneasy Mrs. Earle smiled as in duty bound. A squad of Chinese boys, busy with tiffin-baskets, found time to grin. To this lively actress in the white gown they formed a sylvan audience under the gnarled boughs and the pagoda. "Too late!" called the white-haired giant, indulgently, to the dismounting trio. "Mr. Hackh, you should have come spurring." He started, turned for some rush of overwhelming speech, when a head popped through the window behind them. "Boot and saddle, Mrs. Forrester," announced Heywood. His lean young face was very droll and knowing. "We're leaving, bottom-side." "Thank you so much, Maurice," she answered, perhaps dryly. "You're a dear, to climb all those dreadful stairs." "Oh!" said Heywood, with his gray eyes fastened on Rudolph, "no trouble." All three went down the dark well together. When the company were mounted, and trooping downhill through the camphor shadow, Heywood's pony came sidling against Rudolph's, till legging chafed legging. "You blossomed, old boy," he whispered. "Quite the star, after your comedy turn." He reined aside, grinning. "What price sympathy on a pagoda?" For that moment, Rudolph could have struck down the one sure friend he had in China. "The best?" she echoed, in the same half-whisper as when she had flattered him, that afternoon in the dusky well of the pagoda stairway. "The very best friend? Don't you think you have a better?" Rudolph stared. "Oh, you funny, funny boy!" she cried, with a bewildering laugh, of delight and pride. "I hate people all prim and circumspect, and you--You'd have flown back there straight at him, before my--before all the others. That's why I like you so!--But you must leave that horrid, lying fellow to me." All unaware, she had led him along the blinding white wall of the Forrester compound, and halted in the hot shadow that lay under the tiled gateway. As though timidly, her hand stole up and rested on his forearm. "So sorry." The confined space, narrow and covered, gave to her voice a plaintive ring. "That's twice you protected me, and I hurt you.--You _are_ different. This doesn't happen between people, often. When you did--that, for me, yesterday, didn't it seem different and rather

a little while--" On the rail their hands suddenly touched. He was aware of nothing but the nearness and pallor of her face, the darkness of her eyes shining up at him. All his life seemed to have rushed concentrating into that one instant of extreme trouble, happiness, trembling fascination. Footsteps sounded on the deck behind them; an unwelcome voice called jocosely:-- "Good efening!" The ship's doctor advanced with a roguish, paternal air. "You see at the phosphor, not?" Even as she whipped about toward the light, Rudolph had seen, with a touch of wonder, how her face changed from a bitter frown to the most friendly smile. The frown returned, became almost savage, when the fat physician continued:-- "To see the phosphor is too much moon, Mrs. Forrester?" Had the steamer crashed upon a reef, he would hardly have noticed such a minor shipwreck. Mrs. Forrester? why, then--When the doctor, after ponderous pleasantries, had waddled away aft, Rudolph turned upon her a face of tragedy. "Was that true?" he demanded grimly. "Was what true?" she asked, with baby eyes of wonder, which no longer deceived, but angered. "What the doctor said." Rudolph's voice trembled. "The tittle--the title he gave you." "Why, of course," she laughed.
